name: git
domain: Version control with Git and GitHub
knowledge:
Git is a distributed version control system. Key concepts:

- Working directory: where you edit files
- Staging area: files ready to commit (git add)
- Local repo: committed history (.git/)
- Remote repo: shared history (origin)

Branching model:
- main: stable, production-ready code
- feature branches: one branch per feature/fix
- Never commit directly to main

Commit messages:
- First line: imperative mood, <50 chars (e.g., 'Fix email retry logic')
- Blank line
- Body: explain what and why, not how

PR workflow:
1. Create branch: git checkout -b fix-issue-42
2. Make changes, commit often
3. Push: git push -u origin fix-issue-42
4. Create PR via gh CLI or web
5. Get reviews
6. Merge when approved
examples:
# Create feature branch and PR
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b fix-email-retry
# ... make changes ...
git add -A
git commit -m "Add exponential backoff to email client\n\nFixes #42. Implements retry with delays [1s, 2s, 4s]."
git push -u origin fix-email-retry
gh pr create --title "Fix email retry" --body "Closes #42"

# Review a PR
gh pr checkout 7  # checkout PR locally
# ... test it ...
gh pr review 7 --approve --body "LGTM, tests pass"

# Resolve conflicts
git fetch origin main
git rebase origin/main
# ... fix conflicts ...
git add -A
git rebase --continue
git push --force-with-lease
patterns:
- Always pull before starting work
- One commit per logical change
- PRs should be small and focused
- Write tests before fixing bugs
- Use --force-with-lease not --force
- Squash before merge for clean history
